1	Much of the time [CM] which she might readily have applied to the better efforts of her art [CM] she employed in making coarse garments for the poor [P] It is probable that there was an idea of penance in this mode of occupation [CM] and that she offered up a real sacrifice of enjoyment [CM] in devoting so many hours to such rude handiwork [P] She had in her nature a rich [CM] voluptuous [CM] Oriental characteristic [CM] a taste for the gorgeously beautiful [CM] which [CM] save in the exquisite productions of her needle [CM] found nothing else [CM] in all the possibilities of her life [CM] to exercise itself upon [P] Women derive a pleasure [CM] incomprehensible to the other sex [CM] from the delicate toil of the needle [P] To [PN] [PN] it might have been a mode of expressing [CM] and therefore soothing [CM] the passion of her life [P] Like all other joys [CM] she rejected it as sin [P] This morbid meddling of conscience with an immaterial matter betokened [CM] it is to be feared [CM] no genuine and steadfast penitence [CM] but something doubtful [CM] something that might be deeply wrong [CM] beneath [P] [PB] In this manner [CM] [PN] [PN] came to have a part to perform in the world [P] With her native energy of character [CM] and rare capacity [CM] it could not entirely cast her off [CM] although it had set a mark upon her [CM] more intolerable to a woman s heart than that which branded the brow of [PN] [P] In all her intercourse with society [CM] however [CM] there was nothing that made her feel as if she belonged to it [P] Every gesture [CM] every word [CM] and even the silence of those with whom she came in contact [CM] implied [CM] and often expressed [CM] that she was banished [CM] and as much alone as if she inhabited another sphere [CM] or 1	Here they sat down on a luxuriant heap of [PN] [S] which [CM] at some epoch of the preceding century [CM] had been a gigantic pine [CM] with its roots and trunk in the darksome shade [CM] and its head aloft in the upper atmosphere [P] It was a little dell where they had seated themselves [CM] with a leaf [D] strewn bank rising gently on either side [CM] and a brook flowing through the midst [CM] over a bed of fallen and drowned leaves [P] The trees impending over it had flung down great branches [CM] from time to time [CM] which choked up the current and compelled it to form eddies and black depths at some points [S] while [CM] in its swifter and livelier passages [CM] there appeared a channel [D] way of pebbles [CM] and brown [CM] sparkling sand [P] Letting the eyes follow along the course of the stream [CM] they could catch the reflected light from its water [CM] at some short distance within the forest [CM] but soon lost all traces of it amid the bewilderment of tree [D] trunks and underbrush [CM] and here and there a huge rock covered over with gray lichens [P] All these giant trees and bowlders of granite seemed intent on making a mystery of the course of this small brook [S] fearing [CM] perhaps [CM] that [CM] with its never [D] ceasing loquacity [CM] it should whisper tales out of the heart of the old forest whence it flowed [CM] or mirror its revelations on the smooth surface of a pool [P] Continually [CM] indeed [CM] as it stole onward [CM] the streamlet kept up a babble [CM] kind [CM] quiet [CM] soothing [CM] but melancholy [CM] like the voice of a young child that was spending its infancy without playfulness [CM] and knew not how to be merry among sad acquaintance and events of sombre hue [P] [PB] O brook [E] O foolish and tiresome little brook 1	All the more did the affairs of the great world interest her [CM] when communicated in the letters of high [D] born relations [CN] the way in which fascinating younger sons had gone to the dogs by marrying their mistresses [S] the fine old [D] blooded idiocy of young [PN] [PN] [CM] and the furious gouty humors of old [PN] [PN] [S] the exact crossing of genealogies which had brought a coronet into a new branch and widened the relations of scandal [CM] these were topics of which she retained details with the utmost accuracy [CM] and reproduced them in an excellent pickle of epigrams [CM] which she herself enjoyed the more because she believed as unquestionably in birth and no [D] birth as she did in game and vermin [P] She would never have disowned any one on the ground of poverty [CN] a [PN] [PN] reduced to take his dinner in a basin would have seemed to her an example of pathos worth exaggerating [CM] and I fear his aristocratic vices would not have horrified her [P] But her feeling towards the vulgar [PN] was a sort of religious hatred [CN] they had probably made all their money out of high retail prices [CM] and [PN] [P] [PN] detested high prices for everything that was not paid in kind at the [PN] [CN] such people were no part of [PN] s design in making the world [S] and their accent was an affliction to the ears [P] A town where such monsters abounded was hardly more than a sort of low comedy [CM] which could not be taken account of in a well [D] bred scheme of the universe [P] Let any lady who is inclined to be hard on [PN] [P] [PN] inquire into the comprehensiveness of her own beautiful views [CM] and be quite sure that they afford accommodation for all the lives which have the honor to coexist with hers [P] [PB] With such a mind [CM] active as 1	Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of us all [CN] the peculiar duty of a young man who has been so fortunate as I have been [CM] in early preferment [S] and [CM] I trust [CM] I am resigned [P] Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with her hand [S] for I have often observed [CM] that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our estimation [P] You will not [CM] I hope [CM] consider me as showing any disrespect to your family [CM] my dear madam [CM] by thus 1	[PN] [P] The young divine [CM] whose scholar [D] like renown still lived in [PN] [CM] was considered by his more fervent admirers as little less than a heaven [D] ordained apostle [CM] destined [CM] should he live and labor for the ordinary term of life [CM] to do as great deeds for the now feeble [PN] [PN] [PN] [CM] as the early [PN] had achieved for the infancy of the Christian faith [P] About this period [CM] however [CM] the health of [PN] [P] [PN] had evidently begun to fail [P] By those best acquainted with his habits [CM] the paleness of the young minister s cheek was accounted for by his too earnest devotion to study [CM] his scrupulous fulfilment of parochial duty [CM] and [CM] more than all [CM] by the fasts and vigils of which he made a frequent practice [CM] in order to keep the grossness of this earthly state from clogging and obscuring his spiritual lamp [P] Some declared [CM] that [CM] if [PN] [P] [PN] were really going to die [CM] it was cause enough [CM] that the world was not worthy to be any longer trodden by his feet [P] He himself [CM] on the other hand [CM] with characteristic humility [CM] avowed his belief [CM] that [CM] if [PN] should see fit to remove him [CM] it would be because of his own unworthiness to perform its humblest mission here on earth [P] With all this difference of opinion as to the cause of his decline [CM] there could be no
